an10.51:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an10.51:4.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
an10.51:5.1: “Mendicants, if a mendicant isn’t skilled in the ways of another’s mind, then they should train themselves: ‘I will be skilled in the ways of my own mind.’
an10.51:6.1: And how is a mendicant skilled in the ways of their own mind?
an10.51:6.2: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they examine their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they see any dirt or blemish there, they’d try to remove it.
an10.51:6.3: But if they don’t see any dirt or blemish there, they’re happy with that, as they’ve got what they wished for:
an10.51:6.5: In the same way, reviewing is very helpful for a mendicant’s wholesome qualities.
an10.51:6.6: ‘Am I often covetous or not? Am I often malicious or not? Am I often overcome with dullness and drowsiness or not? Am I often restless or not? Am I often doubtful or not? Am I often angry or not? Am I often corrupted in mind or not? Am I often disturbed in body or not? Am I often energetic or not? Am I often in samadhi or not?’
an10.51:7.1: Suppose that, upon review, a mendicant knows this:
an10.51:7.2: ‘I am often covetous, malicious, overcome with dullness and drowsiness, restless, doubtful, angry, defiled in mind, disturbed in body, lazy, and not in samadhi.’ In order to give up those wholesome qualities, they should apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an10.51:7.3: Suppose your clothes or head was on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an10.51:7.4: Suppose your clothes or head was on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply intense enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an10.51:7.5: In the same way, in order to give up those bad, unwholesome qualities, that mendicant should apply outstanding enthusiasm …
an10.51:8.1: But suppose that, upon review, a mendicant knows this:
an10.51:8.2: ‘I am often content, kind-hearted, free of dullness and drowsiness, calm, confident, loving, pure in mind, undisturbed in body, energetic, and in samadhi.’ Grounded on those wholesome qualities, they should practice meditation further to end the defilements.”
